VT can be further classified as sustained or nonsustained. Nonsustained VT lasts <30 s.
VT is also categorized by the morphology of the QRS complexes:
Monomorphic VT: QRS complexes in the same leads do not vary in contour.
Polymorphic VT: QRS complexes in the same leads do vary in contour.

First-line treatment for symptomatic PVC suppression is β-blocker or calcium channel blocker therapy. Calcium channel blockers, especially verapamil, and β-blockers are first-line therapy for idiopathic VT.

Patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy who present with VT should be considered for angiography and revascularization, if appropriate. In patients with recurrent VT despite β-blocker therapy, antiarrhythmic drug therapy or catheter ablation may be considered.

For unstable patients, immediate electrical cardioversion is indicated. Pulseless VT is treated in the same way as VF.
For hemodynamically stable patients, IV procainamide, amiodarone, and sotalol are therapeutic options.
In patients with structural heart disease, therapy to suppress PVCs does not affect outcomes.
